content: It has been recently stated that the Republican Party is moving more and more to the right (Conservative Beliefs =Fiscal Responsibility + Personal Freedom from Burdensome Government). In my understanding, that means we are struggling to get back to the partys’ Founding Fathers intent for this country. Meanwhile at full speed ahead the Democrat Party is moving away from their birthplace and are morphing into Progressivism and Socialism (Stated By Hillary and the actions of this administration/congress). At first it was denial, now it is becoming a banner. So that has to mean Republicans vs Progressive Socialists.

content: There will always be people who follow a right or far right philosophy. That doesn't make them Republican but it is more likely they will identify with Republicans rather then Democrats. The Republican party leaders realize they have lost the support of the 18 to 34 demographic. Now they must find a Republican identy and philosophy different from the Democrats and appealing to moderate and conservative voters. It's not going to be a "big tent" party but one independent and ambitious people can identify with.
reply: There will always be people who follow a right or far right philosophy. That doesn't make them Republican but it is more likely they will identify with Republicans rather then Democrats. The Republican party leaders realize they have lost the support of the 18 to 34 demographic. Now they must find a Republican identy and philosophy different from the Democrats and appealing to moderate and conservative voters. It's not going to be a "big tent" party but one independent and ambitious people can identify with.

content: quote: They won't have to move very much closer to center to do it, either, if the Dems keep tracking further left. I'm thinking a nice, fat "far left" issue will get passed such as a new gun ban that will once again drive the "middle third" of the electorate back to the GOP as happened in 94. These things always come full circle. Dems and Repubs can't help it...they are programmed to take their majority and try to push the country further left or right than it really wants to go. So we have the pendulum effect...the farther we go back and forth the more chaotic it will become. My issue is that when the country “swings right” I feel it is getting back to the basics. Today on swinging left…we are NOT getting back to the basics. I do not call John McCain a “swinging right movement” however. Respect the heck out of him but he is not to be confused with a conservative.

content: quote: The Republican party leaders realize they have lost the support of the 18 to 34 demographic. Now they must find a Republican identy and philosophy different from the Democrats and appealing to moderate and conservative voters. It's not going to be a "big tent" party but one independent and ambitious people can identify with. I think they have lost the support of the city folk. When you look at Governmental elections the blue are large cities in general. This means the country/non-large cities are soon to be under represented.

content: quote: Originally posted by Fightdirector: quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: quote: Originally posted by ACR26: quote: There's a term for what you're doing here. It's called gilding a turd. Not trying to do anything. Specter leaves because the Republican Party is moving more to the right. What does that mean exactly? The Dems of today are NOT LIKE Pres Kennedy. What does that mean? The Queen herself says she is a Progressive. Thinking is not everybody’s strong suit I understand. Kennedy founded the democratic party? Now that is funny. Fact is the democratic party has been all over the map. Oh and they in fact have progressive roots. The present-day Democratic Party was founded by Thomas Jefferson and James Madison (not by John Kennedy) to oppose the Federalists of Alexander Hamilton. The Federalists believed in "government of wealthy White men, by wealthy White men and for wealthy White men" as did their successors the Whigs, the Know-Nothings and the present-day Republicans. Pretty much spot-on until the late 70's and 80's, when the Democrats went from "social justice" to "socialism" and the GOP had to take up the torch of religeous freedom, family values and small government. It's kind of ironic...the Democratic party is founded by a slave-owning super-wealthy state's rights champion, and the GOP has it's roots with the "all powerful central government" crowd, and in a mere 200 years they pretty much completely switched. FYI, if group can be called the "rich white man's club", I think the Democratic party from it's founding until the present day DEFINITLY qualifies. So, in my book, have no fear...in 200 years, the Dems will once again be led by slave-owning super-rich white men, and the GOP will be the "I don't care who you are as long as you want absolute power consolidated in Washington" club.
